titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lee Clark Johns papers, 1960-2016 RL.11597
titlestmt.author: Megan Lewis

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-04-29 11:31:58 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of materials documenting the professional and community activities of the corporate communications specialist Lee Clark Johns from Tulsa, OK. Materials include Materials include presentations, speeches, business contracts, book drafts and copies, articles, and materials related to professional technical writing associations. There is a scrapbook documenting the Battle for HB 1017, an educational reform bill for the state of Oklahoma. Johns' family history and alumni activities on behalf of Duke University are also included.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into three series: Professional files, Community activities, and Personal files.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of materials documenting the life of Lee Clark Johns, a corporate communications specialst from Tulsa, Oklahoma. Materials include presentations, speeches, business contracts, book drafts and copies, articles, and materials related to professional technical writing associations. There is a scrapbook documenting the Battle for HB 1017, an educational reform bill for the state of Oklahoma. Johns' family history and alumni activities on behalf of Duke University are also included.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lee Clark Johns is a corporate communications professional specializing in business and technical writing. She founded and ran her company, Strategic Communications, for over 30 years. A native of Tulsa, OK, Johns graduated from Duke University with a degree in English. After an early teaching career, she began a career in corporate communications consulting. Her seminars focused on professional writing and presentation skills. Her clients included many national corporations. Johns is also known as the author of the award-winning book "The Writing Coach" (2004). Her article, "The Filing Cabinet Has a Sex Life: Insights of a Professional Writing Consultant" has been widely reprinted. Johns has also served her local community, helping to establish The John Hope Franklin Center for Reconciliation, which addresses race relations in Tulsa. She was also a founding member of Concerned Oklahomans for Reform of Education, a group that helped pass a state education reform bill.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Lee Clark Johns papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2017-0092

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Lee Clark Johns papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publications and customized notebooks, conference presentations and speeches; samples of customized seminar exercies, calendars, ledgers, and financial records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains Duke correspondence, Oklahoma education reform papers, materials from the Tulsa launch of the John Hope Franklin Center for Reconciliation, records from the East Michigan Environmental Action Council and a church-sponsored project in Honduras (Perspire)
